short_description: This function trains a SVM model according to the training set iteratively.
long_description: This function is used to train a SVM model for sparse input data.  The training is a iterative process controlled by the paramters.  We may choose project the attributes to a hash space or explictly record all  the attributes as a list during the training.

argument_clauses.name: Domain
argument_clauses.rDescription: The address of the Queen. The host parameter is the Aster Database Queen’s IP address or hostname.
argument_clauses.description: The address of the Queen. The host parameter is the Aster Database Queen’s IP address or hostname.

argument_clauses.name: Database
argument_clauses.rDescription: The name of the database where the input table is located.
argument_clauses.description: The name of the database where the input table is located.

argument_clauses.name: UserId
argument_clauses.rDescription: The Aster Database user name of the user running this function.
argument_clauses.description: The Aster Database user name of the user running this function.

argument_clauses.name: Password
argument_clauses.rDescription: The Aster Database password of the user.
argument_clauses.description: The Aster Database password of the user.

argument_clauses.name: SSLSettings
argument_clauses.rDescription: A string that includes all the SSL settings, except the password for the truststore.
argument_clauses.description: A string that includes all the SSL settings, except the password for the truststore.

argument_clauses.name: SSLTrustStorePassword
argument_clauses.rDescription: The password for the SSL truststore.
argument_clauses.description: The password for the SSL truststore.

argument_clauses.name: InputTable
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the name of the table or view that contains the training samples.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the name of the table or view that contains the training samples.

argument_clauses.name: ModelTable
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the name for the model table that the function creates (which must not exist).
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the name for the model table that the function creates (which must not exist).

argument_clauses.name: SampleIdColumn
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the name of the input_table column that contains the identifiers of the training samples.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the name of the input_table column that contains the identifiers of the training samples.

argument_clauses.name: AttributeColumn
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the name of the input_table column that contains the attributes of the samples.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the name of the input_table column that contains the attributes of the samples.

argument_clauses.name: LabelColumn
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the name of the input_table column that contains the classes of the samples.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the name of the input_table column that contains the classes of the samples.

argument_clauses.name: ValueColumn
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the name of the input_table column that contains the attribute values. By default, each attribute has the value 1.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the name of the input_table column that contains the attribute values. By default, each attribute has the value 1.

argument_clauses.name: Hash
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies whether to use hash projection on attributes. hash projection can accelerate processing speed but can slightly decrease accuracy. The default value is 'false'. Note: You must use hash projection if the dataset has more features than fit into memory
argument_clauses.description: Specifies whether to use hash projection on attributes. Hash projection can accelerate processing speed but can slightly decrease accuracy. The default value is 'false'. Note: You must use hash projection if the dataset has more features than fit into memory

argument_clauses.name: HashBuckets
argument_clauses.rDescription: Valid only if hash is 'true'. Specifies the number of buckets for hash projection. In most cases, the function can determine the appropriate number of buckets from the scale of the input data set. However, if the dataset has a very large number of features, you might have to specify buckets_number to accelerate the function.
argument_clauses.description: Valid only if Hash is 'true'. Specifies the number of buckets for hash projection. In most cases, the function can determine the appropriate number of buckets from the scale of the input data set. However, if the dataset has a very large number of features, you might have to specify buckets_number to accelerate the function.

argument_clauses.name: Cost
argument_clauses.rDescription: The regularization parameter in the SVM soft-margin loss function: Must be greater than 0.0. The default value is 1.0.
argument_clauses.description: The regularization parameter in the SVM soft-margin loss function: Must be greater than 0.0. The default value is 1.0.

argument_clauses.name: Bias
argument_clauses.rDescription: A non-negative value. If the value is greater than zero, each sample x in the training set will be converted to (x, b); that is, it will add another dimension containing the bias value b. This argument addresses situations where not all samples center at 0. The default value is 0.0.
argument_clauses.description: A non-negative value. If the value is greater than zero, each sample x in the training set will be converted to (x, b); that is, it will add another dimension containing the bias value b. This argument addresses situations where not all samples center at 0. The default value is 0.0.

argument_clauses.name: ClassWeights
argument_clauses.rDescription: Specifies the weights for different classes. The format is: “classlabel m:weight m, classlabel n:weight n”. If weight for a class is given, the cost parameter for this class is weight * cost. A weight larger than 1 often increases the accuracy of the corresponding class; however, it may decrease global accuracy. Classes not assigned a weight in this argument is assigned a weight of 1.0.
argument_clauses.description: Specifies the weights for different classes. The format is: “classlabel m:weight m, classlabel n:weight n”. If weight for a class is given, the cost parameter for this class is weight * cost. A weight larger than 1 often increases the accuracy of the corresponding class; however, it may decrease global accuracy. Classes not assigned a weight in this argument is assigned a weight of 1.0.

argument_clauses.name: MaxStep
argument_clauses.rDescription: A positive integer value that specifies the maximum number of iterations of the training process. One step means that each sample is seen once by the trainer. The input value must be in the range (0, 10000]. The default value is 100.
argument_clauses.description: A positive integer value that specifies the maximum number of iterations of the training process. One step means that each sample is seen once by the trainer. The input value must be in the range (0, 10000]. The default value is 100.

argument_clauses.name: Epsilon
argument_clauses.rDescription: Termination criterion. When the difference between the values of the loss function in two sequential iterations is less than this number, the function stops. Must be greater than 0.0. The default value is 0.01.
argument_clauses.description: Termination criterion. When the difference between the values of the loss function in two sequential iterations is less than this number, the function stops. Must be greater than 0.0. The default value is 0.01.

argument_clauses.name: Seed
argument_clauses.rDescription: A long integer value used to order the training set randomly and consistently. This value can be used to ensure that the same model will be generated if the function is run multiple times in a given database with the same arguments. The input value must be in the range [0, 9223372036854775807]. The default value is 0.
argument_clauses.description: A long integer value used to order the training set randomly and consistently. This value can be used to ensure that the same model will be generated if the function is run multiple times in a given database with the same arguments. The input value must be in the range [0, 9223372036854775807]. The default value is 0.
